00001 #ifndef _UPK_BUDDY_H
00002 #define _UPK_BUDDY_H
00003 /* 
00004 
00005    @mainpage Buddy
00006 
00007    "buddy" is the servicer-restarter component of upkeeper. It has 3 primary design goals:
00008 
00009    1) Reliability - a buddy should never abort or otherwise fail after having been properly initialized. It is being
00010    relied upon to restart other services when they fail, and so what it does, and how it does it must be kept as
00011    simple, and as safe as possible. For instance, there is no runtime heap allocation, and runtime stack allocation is
00012    kept to a minimum, so even with restrictive ulimits, a buddy should not fail after initialization.
00013 
00014    2) Audit - buddy implements a fixed ringbuffer, which it uses to queue events it has monitored, and report those
00015    back to the controller daemon if/when the controller is available. To that end, buddy will send the entire-contents
00016    of its ringbuffer to a controller when it connects to buddy. However, two circumstances exist where the buddy may
00017    need to actively connect the controller, rather than passively waiting for one to come by; they are a) when the
00018    ringbuffer has exceeded 3/4 fullness and b) when a buddy is terminated in a mannor other than a controller shutting
00019    it down.
00020 
00021    3) Flexibility - While buddy must remain somewhat limited in what it can do itself, it has been designed
00022    specifically to remain flexible in how it is used, and amenable to the use of adjuncts to extend and enhance its own 
00023    functionality. In essence, buddy will avoid any behavior that might prevent you from doing whatever you need to do.
00024 
00025 
00026    Buddy operates like this:
00027 
00028    * buddy starts
00029 
00030    * buddy initializes its ringbuffer, some string buffers, and a creates a domain socket to listen for controllers.
00031 
00032    * buddy registers a signal handler for CHLD which sets a flag to restart its managed process.
00033 
00034    * buddy goes into an eventloop where it sits and waits for a controller to tell it what to do.
00035 
00036    * (xyzzy: nothing happens)
00037 
00038    * sometime later, a controller connects to the buddy, and issues a command, eg, start, or runonce, etc.
00039 
00040    * buddy performs the action associated with whatever command it received, and reports back to the controller
00041    everything in its ringbuffer, the last item being the state of the buddy after completing the last action (but not
00042    necessarily the result of that last action; the controller may not obtain a result until some future poll)
00043 
00044    * the 'start' action is the only action that will be monitored. The script associated with the start action is what
00045    buddy will monitor; hence, that script should usually 'exec /path/to/yourservice' after performing any
00046    initialization you may require.
00047 
00048    * buddy supports up to 32 user-defined actions, which can be named anything you like, and can do anything you want;
00049    They receive the pid (and subsequently, the pgrp and sid) of the managed process as their first (and currently, only)
00050    argument. [note that buddy calls these user-defined actions by number, and not by name, as it simplifies the protocol,
00051    and keeps buddy from having to perform (or potentially failing to perform) bounds-checking for string operations]
00052 
00053    If a the monitored child dies during its lifetime, buddy will restart it. If that child is respawning too quickly,
00054    it will be delayed, to help ensure the controller has time to collect information on the failures, and to help
00055    prevent the respawn to negatively impact the system.
00056  */
00057
